headerText: Exploring how an identity system can scale across culture and community.

caseBlocks.textBlock:
Research

Independent venues often lack consistent branding, which makes it hard to stand out in competitive music scenes or build loyalty with younger audiences. I researched how venues in similar cultural districts promoted themselves and noticed a split: some leaned heavily on credibility (clean, minimal branding), while others embraced chaos and DIY aesthetics.

Branding

The CRFT identity system is anchored by a bold, modular logotype that can expand or contract across applications. Typography is set in a stark, modern sans serif to emphasize clarity, paired with a high-contrast black/yellow palette for energy.

Website

For CRFT, the website needed to balance the bold energy of live music with the clarity of a functional event hub. The design uses a modular grid to showcase upcoming shows and ticketing flows, while keeping typography minimal and legible.

Reflection

This project really showed me how basic forms can scale into a strong brand identity. What worked well was establishing clear rules for type and color early, allowing me to keep brand consistency across posters, screens, and social media posts.

caseStudy.content:
Year: 2025

What I did: Branding, UI/UX, Social Media

Completed

Nonprofits I worked with often told me how difficult branding felt, especially when trying to balance being serious and trustworthy while still capturing energy and relevance. CRFT was a conceptual project I took on to explore that challenge in the context of a music venue.
